description:
Aspergillus lentulus is a species of filamentous fungus that belongs to the genus Aspergillus. It is a member of the Aspergillus section Fumigati, which includes several important human and animal pathogenic species.

Aspergillus lentulus is a slow-growing, thermotolerant fungus that typically produces green to grey-green colonies on culture media. The conidiophores (asexual reproductive structures) are relatively short, with a vesicle that bears a uniseriate phialide arrangement (a single row of spore-producing cells).

Morphologically, A. lentulus can be distinguished from the closely related species Aspergillus fumigatus by its slower growth rate, production of smaller conidia (asexual spores), and distinctive colony appearance. Genetically, A. lentulus can be identified by differences in various molecular markers, such as the beta-tubulin and calmodulin gene sequences.

Aspergillus lentulus is considered an emerging opportunistic pathogen that can cause invasive aspergillosis, a severe and potentially life-threatening fungal infection, primarily in immunocompromised individuals. It has been isolated from clinical samples, such as respiratory tract specimens, and is believed to have a global distribution.

Further research is ongoing to better understand the epidemiology, virulence factors, and clinical significance of this fungal species within the context of human and animal health.
